titleStmt.title: Automating Transfer Function Design for Comprehensible Volume Rendering Based on 3D Field Topology Analysis

affiliation.orgName: Graduate School of Humanities and Sciences

analytic.title: Automating Transfer Function Design for Comprehensible Volume Rendering Based on 3D Field Topology Analysis

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: I.3.5 [COMPUTER GRAPHICS]: Computational Geometry and Object Modeling -Curve, surface, solid, and object representations

I.3.6 [COMPUTER GRAPHICS]: Methodology and Techniques -Graphics data structures and data types Volume visualization, direct volume rendering, comprehensible rendering, transfer function, isosurface, Reeb graph, critical surface

abstract.p: This paper describes initial results of a 3D field topology analysis for automating transfer function design aiming at comprehensible volume rendering. The conventional Reeb graph-based approach to describing topological features of 3D surfaces is extended to capture the topological skeleton of a volumetric field. Based on the analysis result, which is represented in the form of a hyper Reeb graph, a procedure is proposed for designing appropriate color/opacity transfer functions. Two analytic volume datasets are used to preliminarily prove the feasibility of the present design methodology.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Direct volume rendering plays an indispensable role in producing semi-translucent images of an entire volume, allowing the user to explore inner structures of volumetric objects in large sampled or simulated 3D datasets [8]. However, the lack of interactivity with the user due to this inherently high complexity of the algorithms makes it difficult for the user to sufficiently adjust rendering-related parameters for generating informative images. It is well-known that one of the most significant factors for determining the quality of volume rendered images is transfer functions, which map physical fields of a given volume dataset to optical properties, such as color and opacity. In order to minimize the number of times for rerendering, an auxiliary mechanism must be developed for designing appropriate transfer functions, based on some available characteristics of a given dataset.
2-1-1 Otsuka, Bunkyo-Ku, Tokyo 112-8610, Japan. fuji@is.ocha.ac.jp, y ftaeko,yurikog@imv.is.ocha.ac.jp

He, et al. present a genetic algorithm approach to searching appropriate transfer functions [4]. However, their approach is rather image-oriented; the generational change is based only on the users' subjective evaluation of volume rendered images. Thus, the final solution depends largely on the users' experiences and intuition, and for any volume dataset, transfer functions giving a good starting point for volumetric exploration cannot be always obtained.

This paper proposes a novel approach to automating the design of transfer functions for comprehensible volume rendering based on the analysis of 3D filed topology. In order to comprehend the complex structure of a volume, it is meaningful to take into account the existence of critical surfaces [7] and to accentuate transfer functions so as to convey the significant structural features of the volume. In this paper, the conventional Reeb graph-based approach to topological modeling of 3D surfaces [10,11] is extended to capture the topological skeleton of a volumetric field by finding critical isosurfaces in the sequence of isosurfaces. The analyzed results are represented in the form of a hyper Reeb graph, which is then traversed to determine appropriate candidates for color/opacity transfer functions.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. The next section shows fundamental concepts related to critical isosurfaces. Section 3 defines the hyper Reeb graph for representing the topological skeleton of volumes, and delineates the procedure for obtaining appropriate choices of transfer functions. Section 4 uses two analytic volume datasets to prove in a preliminary way the effectiveness of the design methodology. In Section 5, the extensibility of the present technique and future research issues are addressed.

div.head: Reeb Graph
div.p: In computer-aided geometric design, complex surfaces are frequently characterized with some special kinds of (curved) edges or vertices. The Reeb graph-based approach [10,11] is known as a typical example of this. Figure 1 shows the Reeb graph of the height function of a torus 1 [11]. The torus in Figure 1(a) can be characterized topologically with four singular points, i.e., a peak, two passes, and a pit. In the Reeb graph of Figure 1

div.head: Critical Isosurfaces
div.p: Next, consider an extension of the above-mentioned Reeb graph to the topological volume modeling. First, the entire volume dataset is decomposed by its field values. Of course, in the digital setting, the decomposition leads to a countable set of isosurfaces. Then, once a common direction for height function is given, the topological skeleton of each isosurface can be represented with the traditional Reeb graph. By examining the homotopic equivalence (structure of Reeb graphs) of consecutive isosurfaces, an isolated isosurface may be identified, which is herein referred to as a critical isosurface. Also, the field value for identifying a critical isosurface is called the critical field value.

An analytic volume dataset, called H2 hereafter, is given as a running example [3]: By field focusing with interval volumes [3], it appears that the H2 volume dataset has only one critical iso-density surface, on which the single lower iso-density surface is split into two higher parts around the two nuclei (Figure 2

div.head: Designing Appropriate Transfer Functions
div.p: The basic idea of designing appropriate transfer functions based on a hyper Reeb graph is to emphasize the existence of critical isosurfaces in terms of both color (hue) and opacity. The color transfer function is designed so that the change in hue with respect to field value is uniform except for a constant jump a ( i+1 ; i) at each critical field value i (Figure 4

div.head: RESULTS
div.p: AVS5 [1] was chosen as the software platform for developing a pilot processing environment. In-house modules for automatic construction of a hyper Reeb graph from an input volume data and designing transfer functions have been developed. Since this research is still underway, at this point both the hyper Reeb graph construction and transfer function accentuation were carried out manually using the in-house "interval volume" extraction module [3], which can be used to allow for topologically-consistent isosurfacing [13].
For the purpose of volume rendering evaluation, the AVS tracer (ray-casting) module was utilized. The following experiments were performed on an SGI O2 system (CPU: R5000, Clock: 180MHz, RAM: 192MB).

First, Figure 5 shows experimental results with the H2 volume dataset (64 64 64). It is obvious from the figures that the improved transfer functions (a = 0:3 b = 0:04 0 = 0:03 c = 0:01), where the topological skeleton of volumetric field are taken into account, leads to more comprehensible volume rendering results. Next, a more complicated example of an analytically-defined volume dataset (128 128 64), called 3Blobbies hereafter, is considered. The field function (r) is defined by:
(r(x y z)) = a 2 (rA) + b 2 (rB ) + c 2 (rC ) S a(rA) = e ; jr A j b(rB) = e ; jr B j a(rC) = e ; jr C j S = 0:273

where rA, rB, rC denote vectors defined with reference to the fixed points A(0:17 0:098 0:25), B(0:33 0:098 0:25), and C(0:25 0:34 0:25), respectively. succeeded to reveal the inner structure of the volume dataset more clearly.

div.head: DISCUSSION
div.p: This paper has presented the initial results of the 3D field topology analysis to automate transfer function design for comprehensible (0.00) (1.00) (0.70) (0.89) volume rendering. The preliminary experiments with the two analytic volume datasets clarified that:
The improved hue transfer function is useful for visually grasping homotopically equivalent isosurfaces.
The improved opacity transfer function is beneficial for emphasizing the existence of critical isosurfaces.
Combined use of the two improved transfer functions provides the viewer with effective visual cues for understanding the internal structure of volume datasets.

The present transfer function design methodology is quite general; it can be applied to the forward approach to volume rendering, such as splatting and cell projection [8]. Moreover, the methodology is independent of the mesh type of an input volume dataset, if a sequence of isosurfaces can be extracted from the dataset.
Yet another effective usage of the hyper Reeb graph is to make indirect volume visualization more sophisticated:

Simultaneous display of semi-transparent isosurfaces, whose level values are critical field values as well as the middle point of homotopy equivalent field intervals. Plausible values for relative opacity can be determined reflecting the mutual relationships among the length of the intervals.

It is attractive to decompose a given volume into interval volumes with homotopy equivalent field intervals [3]. Such interval volumes are expected to show physically meaningful volume clustering. Representative isosurfaces taken from a hyper Reeb graph can also serve as an effective set of basic frames for the flip book approach to volume rendering [2].

There remain a number of issues related to the present approach for future work. It is first required to prove the feasibility of the transfer function design methodology with practical sampled or simulated datasets, which are likely to include a large number of critical isosurfaces. In a previous paper [12], a metric, termed V C M , for volumetric coherence has been proposed. One candidate method for prioritizing critical isosurfaces using the VCM metric is described as follows. If the VCM value for a given volume dataset is greater than a pre-specified threshold, downsize the original volume or simplify each isosurface [9,5] for hierarchically merging neighboring homotopically equivalent field intervals to control the LoD of the hyper Reeb graph.

As clearly seen from the above description, a hyper Reeb graph is an unambiguous, but non-unique representation of a topological skeleton of a given volume field. It is crucial to choose an optimal direction for sampling height field functions. Hemisphere mapping [6] is considered to be one of the convincing solutions to this problem.

Also it is a challenging theme to take advantage of the present design approach to visually explore a time-dependent volume (4D) dataset, just like a hydrogen ion-atom collision shown in [3], where volume field topology is drastically time-evolving.

figure.figDesc: (b), these singular points are represented as nodes and are connected to each other by an edge representing a set of homotopically equivalent connected contours on consecutive cross-sectional planes. As clearly seen from the figure, a Reeb graph can provide a topological skeleton of a 3D surface. For the precise definition of a Reeb graph, see reference[10].

figure.head: 3 TRANSFER FUNCTION DESIGN PRO- CEDURE 3.1 Hyper Reeb Graph
figure.figDesc: topological analysis of a volumetric field carried out in Section 2.2 can be represented with an extension of the traditional Reeb graph, referred to herein as the hyper Reeb graph, which gives the basic reference structure for designing appropriate transfer functions, as shown in Section 3.2. The hyper Reeb graph is a hyper graph, which is composed of two layers of topological data specification. The top layer of the graph is a linear directed graph connecting nodes with critical field values, plus boundary nodes with maximum and minimum field values in an ascending order. Each node retains the corresponding Reeb graph as its weight at the bottom layer. Also for each edge, the homotopically equivalent Reeb graph is assigned as its structural weight.Figure 3illustrates the hyper Reeb graph for the H2 volume dataset. Here, the height function is defined along the y-axis. Note that the middle node v2 with the critical field value 0.52 is differentiated from the boundary nodes v1 and v3 by depicting it with a solid circle.
figure.note: Figure 3 Hyper Reeb graph for H2 volume dataset.

body.note: Altering directions for defining height function gives different Reeb graphs for the torus[10].
